metadata.sermon_title: A Week’s Walk into a New Mind
metadata.sermon_start_end: When I was confirmed on Palm Sunday at age thirteen, we had to memorize the answers to 128 catechism questions. The hardest one that we dreaded was question 72: “Wherein is the humiliation and exaltation of Christ briefly described?” [...] You can look it up. It is question #72; it is the pivot point of the catechism. It is the best hymn of our faith. It is the truth of our life!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Philippians 2:5-11 as a central anchor, but it fails Dekker's requirement of finding what is in THIS text that is nowhere else. Instead of focusing on the unique Christological 'kenosis' or the specific hymn structure, it treats the text as a summary of the whole Gospel or a general 'journey' of Holy Week. It risks becoming a speech about 'the gospel' rather than an exposition of this specific pericope.
quotes: In these verses Paul has taken over a very old hymn... It is all there!
The humiliation and exaltation of Christ is briefly expressed in Philippians 2:5–11
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the unique linguistic and theological singularity of the 'form of God' vs 'form of a slave' contrast in this specific text, rather than using it as a general summary of the liturgical week.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The exegesis is superficial. While it mentions the text is a 'hymn' and refers to the 'Roman-Jewish authorities,' it lacks depth regarding the Greek terms (morphe, kenosis) or the specific socio-political context of Philippi as a Roman colony. The comparison of the cross to an 'electric chair' is anachronistic and replaces historical exegesis with modern shock value.
quotes: even death in the Roman electric chair.
Paul is concerned... with the reality of the church, the specific little congregation in the Greek city of Philippi
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Utilize the original Greek concepts of 'status' and 'honor' in the Roman world to explain why 'emptying oneself' was a radical theological claim, rather than using modern political analogies.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its critique of 'imperial claims' and 'cynical power,' which aligns with Dekker's demand for zeitgeist awareness. However, it leans toward general socio-political categories (greed, fear, scarcity) rather than specific congregational life. The call to 'look to the interests of others' is a direct application of the text.
quotes: contradict the cynical power of greed and fear and scarcity and anger and anxiety that governs the world.
Look not to your preference or your ideology, but consider what is best for others in the community.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond general political categories like 'imperial world' to specific, local examples of how the 'mind of Christ' challenges the current psychological or social state of the specific congregation.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat linear path: first the hymn (exposition), then the context of the letter (exposition), then the call to the church (application). While there is some mixing, the 'present of revelation' Dekker seeks is hindered by the repetitive structure and the separation of the 'then' of the hymn from the 'now' of the congregation.
quotes: But Paul plays a trick on us that the lectionary committee did not want us to notice. You see that the early hymn begins in verse 5. But you would guess would you not, that there are before these verses 1–4?
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the 'mind of Christ' directly into the description of modern 'willfulness' so that the text and the hearer are 'expounded' simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly addresses 'misery' (willfulness, selfish will, imperial oppression) and 'redemption' (Christ's obedience and exaltation). 'Gratitude' is present in the 'glad praise' of the church. However, the 'misery' is often framed more as a political or psychological problem than a theological misery 'before God.'
quotes: get your mind off yourself and your willfulness.
submission to the goodness of God finally will prevail
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by emphasizing the impossibility of man attaining this 'mind' without the radical grace of the 'emptied' God.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present in the contrast between the 'imperial world' and the 'governance of love.' However, the seriousness of being 'lost' is softened. The sermon suggests we are 'invited' to the journey, but the ultimate consequence of choosing the 'broad way' of Caesar/self is not sharply articulated as 'destruction.'
quotes: The news is that submission to the goodness of God finally will prevail and no power on earth will finally defeat the power of love.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the reality of 'temporal loss'—the actual perishing of a community or life that refuses the mind of Christ—to increase the urgency of the sermon.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes Christ's divinity ('form of God') and his role as the source of new life. It avoids making the sermon merely about human ethics by grounding the 'new mind' in the 'mind of Christ.' Grace is the underlying theme of the 'Easter surprise.'
quotes: Christ is his life. All of Scripture is the one garment in which the whole Christ comes to us.
Jesus is Lord in a way that contradicts the imperial claims of Caesar.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that the 'imitation of Christ' (v. 5) does not overshadow the 'work of Christ' (v. 6-11) as the sole ground of salvation.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1150 words, the sermon would take about 11-12 minutes to deliver. This is significantly below Dekker's minimum of 20 minutes. Consequently, the 'breadth' required for 'depth' is missing; the sermon feels like a series of rapid points rather than a deep immersion in the text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition of the hymn's specific clauses and the application to the congregation's specific 'misery' to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily in its brevity and its tendency to treat the specific Bible passage as a general summary of the Gospel rather than a unique revelation. It lacks the exegetical depth (Greek/Hebrew context) required by Dekker and substitutes historical rigor with modern political analogies. While it successfully identifies Christ as the telos and attempts a concrete application to the 'zeitgeist,' it lacks the 'breadth' necessary for true homiletical depth.
strengths: Clear Christocentric focus where Christ is the goal (telos) of the message.
Concrete attempt to address the 'zeitgeist' and the political implications of the Gospel.
Effective use of the Heidelberg Catechism as a framing device for the theological structure.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 11 minutes) failing the requirement for 'breadth.'
Anachronistic exegesis (e.g., 'electric chair') that avoids the hard work of historical-linguistic exposition.
Lack of the 'seriousness of being lost' (Thesis 6), making the 'two ways' feel like an optional invitation rather than a life-and-death choice.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an inadequate sermon according to Dekker's criteria. It functions more as a theological 'speech' or a liturgical reflection than a formal 'exposition and application' of a specific text. It lacks the necessary length for depth and the specific exegetical rigor required of a minister.
